moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 exd4 4. Nxd4: the idea here was to borrow an approach used by Zuckerman in a game vs. Nikolic which appeared in the Jan. '71 chess life & review magazine.
moves.4... Nf6 5. Nc3 Be7 6. Bf4 O-O 7. Qd2 Nc: the way this game develops this may be the lemon here.  Perhaps the direct 11 g4 here instead.
moves.11... Nd7 12. Kb1: played to prevent an exchange of bishops but black now comes up with a pair of good moves back to back.
moves.12... Bf6 13. Qd2 Nc5: suddenly it becomes plain that black is threatening a ferocious attack with ... b5! if white goes in for passive defense with 14 f3.
moves.14. Be3: offering a pawn by 14 ... Bxc3 15 Qxc3 Nxe4 16 Qd4 with some counterchances.
moves.14... b5 15. Bxc5 dxc5 16. Nd5 c4 17. Qe: some careful thought was necessary here as there are some possible pins which reduce the viability of an e5 by white.
moves.19. f4 Qb4 20. c3 Qa5: it is difficult to read if this was an oversight by black.  an alternative was 20 ... Qe7 but 21 g4 has to reckoned with by black.
moves.21. e5 Be7 22. f5: white had to lay off of the "c" pawn because of ... c6!
moves.22... Rad8 23. Bxc4 Rxd5: instead 23 ... Qb6 was a real possibility playing for a draw with the opposite colored bishops.
moves.27... g6 28. e6 fxe6 29. Bxe6+ Kh8 30. f: the pawn on f7 creates some tactical possilities and prevents black from playing ... Re8.
moves.30... b4 31. Rf1 Bg7 32. Bb3:
this gives black a problem to solve.  32 ... c6 loses to 33 Qe8+ Bf8 34 Qe5+! Bg7 35 f8Q+!
32 ... Qb8 looks to be black's only move.  white has some pressure on black, but the win needs to be figured out.  33 cxb4 would give white a second pawn but the issue would remain undecided.
moves.32... Qb5 33. f8=Q+: forcing mate or loss of the queen.
